[h1] Alright. [/h1]
[h3] Here is my opinion after 100%-ing the entire game and getting all notebook badges and steam 100%. [/h3]

[h2] This part covers the game in general (all DLCs included, if you want to know about each individual DLC, just check them): [/h2]

[list]
[*]A casual game where you cook, surpassing Gordon Ramsay in culinary talent and turning the working hours into Hell's kitchen
[*]An amazing soundtrack. You can go to most places in Gensokyo, all having a unique theme
[*]A very beginner friendly game in order to get into the Touhou Project
[*]The art style is fantastic and the gameplay is very fluid
[*]During my personal playthought, I haven't encountered many bugs aside from the random steam cloud error when launching the game sometimes. (You don't lose any save files, it's fixable just by relaunching the game)
[*]The gameplay can be repetitive for some people if you take your time it shouldn't be an issue
[*]You'll find most of the characters of the Touhou Project
[*]There's many references to pop culture hidden throughout the game
[*]If you have the money, you should definitely get the game at full price. Even with all DLCs it cost less than most AAA games
[/list]

[h2] This part is for main game only: [/h2]

[list]
[*]The story is fairly easy to understand even without knowing any of the characters.
[*]For the base price of the game, it is definitly worth it as you'll get a long [b] long [/b] playtime if you don't skip any of the dialogues.
[*]The steam 100% can be achieved without any of the DLCs.
[*] The game's intro is  [b] AMAZING [/b] 
[/list]

[h2] Did I mention they are releasing an anime for this game? [/h2]

[h1] Overall 10/10 game, get your entire family to play this masterpiece of a game. [/h1]

If you know nothing about Touhou this is a great forray into the lore even as a Fanon game. A plate up style cooking simulator, enjoy creating your menus, serving unique customers and helping one bird live her true dream.
coziest game ever. best way to not pay attention in class. 10/10
Quite a comfort game to play with a good tie-in to the world of Gensokyo and Touhou Project, even if it's not all canon. Nonetheless, a great one to enjoy.

Whilst im still not finished with the main game, this game is INCREDIBLE!! its super fun and easy to play though it makes you think and plan ahead for the night, giving the perfect combo of cosy game and problem solving. I will admit, some things are a little difficult like trying to find food for tasks with a combination of tags you dont have in one meal (im not sure if i can combine ingredients for the day tasks, i havent found out yet)

The characters are charming and portrayed in a loving and respectful way, theres also quite a bit to do during the day like gather ingredients, talk to characters, start and finish side quests, learn new recipies, pre cook for the night, and more though some things i wish you would be told like going to the donation box on the left at Hakurei Shrine will give you goodies, some you can use to buy outfits at Rinnosukes. alot of love was put in this game and it shows. 

the controls are super easy, i started out on a controller but found it easy to play on keyboard (which is rare for me at the moment, especially as i am on a laptop)

the game is also long (to me) but not in a tiring way. ive been playing on and off due to my College studies and recently before calling it a day i usually reach a new part in the main plot, meaning after a long day, i get to come right back to it.

The game itself is fun, characters are cute, graphics are cute, story is not very serious but it's good enough, most importantly it doesn't break characters it works with.

The thing to note compared to normal restaurant simulators are the characters - most of the named characters from Touhou are here as special visitors that have unique tastes and are a bit of a nuisance by not ordering specific food and instead just making vague requests - but they are critical to please as they can reward or punish you in a way that affects everything else for some time.

What I can critique is interface and general clunkiness of the game UX (user expirience). I think it's a product of the game being supported but not rewritten nor continued with a sequel, in the span of many years. It's good that you get the best experience even without buying new content, but there is a limit to how much they can reasonably change for better when the game is already made and any change might break something.

But what other fangame gets sold on Steam, with 6 DLC (ones that add new content, not ones that just split essential parts of story and gameplay), fire soundrack, and gets a whole slice of life anime (also being sold on Steam)? And on sale you can get all of that for a price that would be fair just for the game (except anime of course, it didn't come out yet as of writing the review)?

Frankly, I don't know much about the Touhou games, but I've been consuming fanmade works involving the characters for a very long time. I absolutely love this game--it's so fun, the art is spectacular, and the story gives me a newfound appreciation for characters in the series that I didn't really bat an eye at before. I love how the character dialogue ranges from a slice-of-life style clash of character dynamics to real discussion of philosophy, folklore, and religion befitting their personalities. I think it might be a daunting amount of information for an "outsider" of the series who isn't thoroughly knowledgeable of the events that occur in the games, but it's still easily consumable for folks who don't know Touhou and I like it that way.

As a fan of the Touhou universe I adore this game and had a lot of fun with it, it's probably in the top 3 Touhou fan games of all time especially for the very reasonable listed price. However, it is a flawed game and I wouldn't recommend it for anyone who doesn't know and like Touhou.

Positives:
+ Great pricing
+ Large amount of content, from characters to locations to recipes
+ Generally good gameplay experience, especially if you enjoy casual games, optimising and routines
+ Portrays a large region of Touhou's universe with a charming nod to both canon and fanon.
+ A good sense of humour, if a bit memey
+ Very satisfying to have the rhythm gameplay sync with the background music

Negatives:
- The English localisation is very poor in some places.
- it's missing some key QoL features, such as negatively filtering dishes by tags or by work station. There is a huge problem which is that there are so many recipe tags, you need to be able to filter the tags! The tags should at least be sorted alphabetically.
- Awkward mouse control in menus. In particular, there is one menu in DLC5 where you have to make 150 mouse clicks to complete a purchase...
- The game's pacing is very slow and can be very repetitive. This is especially horrible if you don't have the DLCs.
- There is no challenge whatsoever. I really like casual games... but this game takes it to extreme levels. You will never have a guest leave due to impatience unless you leave the game to go make a meal IRL.
- Disappointing rhythm elements. The game feels like a sophisticated cafe management game with a very basic rhythm game shoehorned into it. The rhythm game is very lenient with timing and has no "impact" on the beats, which can make it feel very unsatisfying. It could have done with more work, currently it feels like a chore.
- The soundtrack. There are only a couple of tracks I could listen to on repeat without growing to hate them, and this game sure does expect you to listen to them on repeat.

A birdie named Mystia embarks on a quest to harem every one of Touhou's characters in what is the pinnacle of all fan-games of this multi-decade old series. It's no lie: this game is flooded with backbreaking love. With what I believe to be an award-winning soundtrack, dialogue giving an equal weight to every character you meet, & an aesthetic that'll remain perpetually fresh no matter the date, this is THE homage to Touhou.

Mystia's Izakaya with all its inclusion of its DLC 5 (& total translation as of patch 4.2.1) is totally completed. It's incredibly affordable price with all its DLCs (& soundtracks) - even with no discounts - makes this a no-bird-brainer for anyone already reading this page. Its gameplay loop catches up to latch on even for those unaccustomed (like myself) to the genre.

Sadly all good things must eventually reveal their dark sides: the main gameplay loop simply takes too long! It took me 80 hours to level my relationships to max with all the base game characters & an additional 125 to max with every DLC's characters. Maxing your relationships with all characters is important because it's the only way to unlock the boss fights, cooking assistants, skills, recipes, outfits, auto-gatherers, & equipment. This IS the main gameplay loop & it's IMPORTANT that you do this to turn this into a casual-feeling game rather than a competitive one. I have 205 hours on this game played over 75 days, that is almost 3 hours of playing ONLY this game a day! That is some serious commitment to be making to a game, it's starting to rival even MapleStory. At certain times, I felt like I'd rather pull weeds than play.

I don't know if the developers should change how long it takes, as the time took with each character feels perfect at the same time. There's no incentives to come back to areas you've already finished. With being able to easily receive a perfect rating with dishes, there's no reason to go above & beyond with ingredients. The singing while cooking mini-game is cheese-able by spamming buttons, I wished they gave an option to lean into it to be harder as I find it great at bringing the players back to attention.

Despite that, if you remember the passion you felt in my first paragraph, you'd know that this game is timeless. I sincerely recommend that you'd play it.

I've finished the main story and almost all of the DLCs (almost done with DLC5) and the value you get for the price (especially if you get everything on sale) is insane! I didn't know anything about Touhou before playing this and never touched a game from the series or any other fan game before, yet I loved this game so much. I can only imagine how fun a Touhou fan is gonna have with this! There is a wide variety of characters and they're all so adorable and cute (and also very relatable sometimes). 


The mechanics are just right for me, simple yet challenging at times but not enough to stress me out. I love that you can play it the way you prefer, getting orders out ASAP - or taking the time to come up with the perfect order for your rare customers, trying to figure out how many liked tags you can fit into the dish, without it negatively impacting the gameplay (since the working time isn't progressing when you need to look things up in the diary). 

Leveling friendships feels rewarding and is fun (though frustrating at times - not in a bad way, you'll understand when you're that tinyyyy bit away from maxing them out and they just decide to not show up, even though you personally invited them). 

It also includes a variety of tracks you can play as a rhythm game, though they are completely optional! I can't say much about them, since I'm not a rhtyhm game fan (spared them a glance once or twice) but if you're a fan of those, you will not be disappointed. 

I definitely suggest getting the game + the DLCs at once as I felt like they enriched the experience of playing through the main story (with the extra locations, characters, recipes, etc.) but you can also easily play the main story first and decide to go for the DLCs after (to see if the game is for you).

Story is decent but broken up too much and slow paced, super cute art with likeable character design, main game-play of making food is and serving is fun but remembering so many dishes and customers is annoying, gathering ingredients gets tiring after more areas open up, too many systems layered on top make it too complex to have some simple fun

The game is complicated in an unnecessary way. I'd played many games of the genre, this one is hugely bloated (too many tags and the playing music is badly designed but critical) and the control for pc is atrocious. Overall, won't recommend if you look for cozy, chill game.

Please make an accessibility feature for players who don't feel comfortable serving alcohol.
For instance, changing the term "alcohol" to "juice" or something else.

I'm willing to change or delete this negative review if this feature is added or if I end out making a mod for it.
If anyone comes out with a mod to fix it, please let me know.

Thanks.
